mainText.attr1: Base Management:
Void Destroyer is primary a - combat oriented - game. However you do have some control over bases and their production.
Key Concepts:
Bases have crew which produce and consume resources.
You can allocate crew to three resources - energy, food and ore.
Not all bases are able to produce ore.
When over 25% of the crew gets allocated to a resource:
A bonus to production gets added - increasing the higher the crew %
Crew consume food and energy - but do not consume ore.
If a base lacks food and/or energy - crew population will decrease.
Platform crew also consume resources - but do not produce resources.
Platforms sometimes consume resources - as upkeep (see Building Platforms topic).
How to manage production:
Manipulate the three sliders to allocate crew production percentages.
When you increase one slider - the other sliders will decrease.
When you decrease one slider - the other sliders will increase.
Because there are three sliders - sometimes you will need to - lock - a slider to be able to allocate as desired.
Example (image on the right):
Energy: There is 2944 units of energy, with 25% of the crew production.
Each of the 25% of the crew produces 5.72 units of energy for a total of 48 units.
Due to consumption - there is a net gain of 17 units of energy.
Food: The food production slider is locked - allowing to move the other sliders without changing the food slider.
There is a net loss of 7 food, however due to having food stores of 3688 units there is no shortage.
Crew: Due to there being no shortages of energy and crew - crew population increased by 3.
For Math Majors:
If you notice - the % pictured in the image add up to over 100% - this is due to (mostly) rounding up in the displayed text %
Managing base economy via sliders has been influenced by the classic game - Master of Orion.

Early on in Void Destroyer's development - I started writing out a complex hierarchy of raw resources, intermediate resources, and final products. I realized that this process didn't appeal much to me (wasn't having fun) and that other games have much more complex resource and production mechanics. So I decided to stick with the RTS route of a few basic resources.
